job_title: People Leadership in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Magnet Status, Level 1 Trauma Center, Leadership and Staff resources, strong and supportive RN Union, beautiful campus, and for the most part, working with teammates who are here for the right reasons. Large health system with great benefits (a little pricey compared to some other orgs)
cons:
Cost of living - Do you have any resources to housing to new employees? Average rent for an 899 sq ft apartment is around $3,600. The median home price in Palo Alto is $3,324,700.

Disconnect between Senior Leaders (C-Suite and VPs), operational leaders (Managers/Directors) and line staff. Senior leaders have a history of not listening to recommendations from their front-line / operational management staff who are doing the work on a daily basis. When recommendations are provided, the response is usually, "Thank you for your feedback, however, we are going a different direction." The different direction is usually a recommendation that was already implemented by a previous leadership team and did not work. Also, why hire external consultants in your area, when you already have senior staff who are fully capable of implementing positive changes internally? If you empower your staff to speak up and listen to these recommendations, the organization would be further along in our journey to be top 5 in the nation vs where we are currently.

All of this can be fixed. I have been here for many years and still believe in the potential of our organization. We just need more leaders who are willing to step up, put aside egos or blame, and promote effective change without simply agreeing just to appease their leader. 

I believe in you, Stanford. Let's do this.

review_title: Decent job, decent pay. Some office politics.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
It's a great entry level position for anyone interested in a health care administrative role. It's like any other entry level registration job. Decent pay and benefits. Very competitive to get into, though. Whenever there are open positions, they're usually taken by someone within the company or by someone who's been referred by a current employee. Not impossible to get in if you're not in either of those categories, just harder.

You're never really in just one department unless you're an OG and have seniority over everyone. If you're newer, expect to cover different areas or get stuck in a department that nobody else wants to cover. Shifts are also by seniority, so if you're newer then you'll most likely have to take the closing shift. Some managers are great to work with and there are opportunities to work on different projects.
cons:
Some managers give priority to staff that they're friends with. If you're not friends with them then they won't be as responsive to you or will straight up ignore you. 

You have to pay for parking. The parking lots aren't too far away. They're walking distance (about 15 min or so) and there are also shuttles available.

review_title: Low Pay, Rude Management/Directors, & High Deductible Insurance Plans
job_title: Clinical Clerical Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Hospital is located in a nice area if you’d like to go for walks on your lunch break.
- Employee parking isn’t cheap but it’s not as expensive as some of the other hospitals in the area.
- The hospital has shuttles to take you to the multiple buildings that make up the hospital & clinics.
- Some truly amazing employees but they’re under incompetent managers & directors who don’t care about them at all.
cons:
- Pay is much lower than other hospitals in the area
- No bonuses unless you’re a manager and this bonuses are not adequate for the level of work they’re doing
- Staff receive small yearly salary increases
- Medical insurance plans offered have very high out of pocket deductibles and they change the plans quite often because they’re constantly seeking plans that cost less for them to offer. Unfortunately whenever they would change the plan our benefits would be worse then they were before. 
- If you chose to go to Stanford for your care their bills are huge. The lab charges are outrageous - I was billed over $2600 for basic labs which meant that after one lab visit I had met my outrageous $2400 deductible.
- Management spends most of their time focused of trying to get certain employees who they don’t like fired.
- Management treats staff like they’re not at their level. They talk down to them & make hurtful, rude, and demeaning comments towards their employees. This is even tolerated in staff huddles and meetings. I complained multiple times after hearing management make foul, and at times even racist comments, but the managers engaging in this behavior were somehow able to keep their positions. It was very sad to see how they treated some of the staff. 
- Favoritism given to employees who are related to directors or other managers. These employees receive multiple career advancement opportunities not offered to others, higher pay, & are promoted with ease.
- Directors only care about saving money to increase their bonuses. They don’t care about the staff. They fire senior employees because they can hire new staff for a cheaper cost or promote someone into a role while having them maintain their previous position. So it’s not really a promotion. It’s way more work added on to your already full plate for a few dollars more an hour. Plus they’ll make you salary to avoid having to pay you overtime which actually means you’re making less because you’re working overtime constantly for free.

review_title: Career Ladder Headaches, Lack of Diversity, Competency Exploitation
job_title: Informatics Educator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Good Pay (though inequitable among people doing the same job duties) 
Good Benefits
Prestigious Name/resume builder 
Ability to learn a lot about health care if you take the initiative 
Opportunity for a decent work/life balance if you can advocate for yourself
cons:
Leadership: 
An employee's experience at SHC/on the Informatics Education team is almost entirely determined by your direct leadership. There is no standardization to onboarding and you are largely left to figure things out for yourself or rely on the kindness of people who have been in your position to take pity on you and help. 
 
Overall, leadership, from the C-Suite to the Director level, is wholly out of touch with their employees and what they do and will do absolutely nothing to advocate for your well-being let alone even seeming to care about their job or the people around them at all. 

Career Advancement and Compensation: 
Competence and ingenuity are not rewarded with raises or promotions unless you are loud enough and aggressive enough to claw your way up to what you deserve. Instead, people with those qualities are rewarded for doing good work by being given more work. Employees who do well will regularly outperform their job duties on paper for 10's of thousands of dollars less than they should be receiving for doing so. 

Career advancement is stymied by nonsense career ladder processes. Management knows who they will/will not give positions to prior to career ladder applications/interviews (leaders often tell employees whether or not they should even apply for a desired position based on whether they know they will get it or not) but they still make existing employees jump through hoops during a 6 month long process to receive a single step promotion on an unnecessarily long ladder and a 5% pay increase. 

Diversity: 
SHC puts on a very good, but VERY fake face when it comes to diversity. The C-Suite is largely full of old white men and it shows in the way that the company operates. SHC is stuck in the dark ages in so many ways. Almost all efforts to promote diversity in the workforce and to support employees of color are completely empty "check a box" type of actions. The culture of the company is such that the retention of a diverse workforce is nearly impossible, because SHC has set up an environment in which only people who fit into the "cultural majority" are rewarded. At the very least there need to be BIPOC in positions of leadership in every department, and in the higher levels of leadership such as the C-Suite. Every employee should be required to complete an implicit biases training, and all hiring processes should be overhauled and standardized across the organization to control for biases. 

Also, diversity of opinion and questioning leadership are big no-no's and will lead to being covertly or overtly treated differently than colleagues who blindly follow leadership's nonsense.

job_title: Hospital Patient Transporter in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
1. Benefits are really good - including pet insurance for full-time employees! 
2. A well-oiled machine of a place, so there's no uncertainty on what the job is and what your responsibilities are
3. Transporters get so much exercise, so you WILL lose weight. 
4. You'll see and experience some incredible and often emotional things working in a hospital - for example, you'll meet people who are dead or dying.
5. There was a mix of employees who were only there for a year or two, and people who were there for 20 years. Good job for students, since you can work weekends or nights as a part-timer, but also inflexible scheduling. Per diem is a nightmare. Good for full-time since it's such a stable job.
cons:
1. While I was there, there was almost a union strike. Our pay was less than other hospitals in the same area. They eventually compromised, but it was pretty wild for 6 months. 
2. Job satisfaction really depends on who the manager / supervisor is. While I was there, a shift in management was really difficult to handle, since the first guy was more understanding about his employees having lives than the second guy. 
3. Point system for late / absent days feels dehumanizing - you are definitely just a replaceable cog in the machine. 
4. Job requires a lot of energy to be constantly personable, walk all over the large hospital, and finish transports within a time window. 
5. While I was there, I was told it was better to come to work sick (and hopefully be sent home) than to call out. Pretty terrible employee-to-employer trust there.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- The name on your resume.
- Educational Assistance and free Caltrain.
- The C-I-Care culture is great.
- Annual across the board increases - only if you don't have a write up.
- Benefits and Wellness Program is good.
cons:
- Only will hire or promote you if you know someone who works in the department.
- Very political, in all departments.
- Promotes people only if they can't fill the position, so a lot of the times the person who is promoted to that role is not qualified for the position.
- Hires you based on your personality. So you can have all the right skills, but if they don't like your personality, you won't get it. If you have none of the skills, but you are bubbly and outgoing, then you go it.
- Management does not know how much work their team actually has.
- They alter your time card to avoid paying meal penalties.
- Under staffed departments - not only in the corporate/business departments, but also short staffed within the hospital.
- The shift is M-F, 8am-5pm. There is so much work, and they don't want to hire additional head count, so you may be required to stay till 10pm at night or come in on the weekends.
- Employees have so much work to get done, but management does not know their employee's work load and they won't approve OT, so employees will stay and work off the clock to ensure job safety.

pros: Amazing benefits, excellent pay, awesome reputation.
cons: The RN New Grad Residency Program has its good and bad.  I was expecting a pace that was more conducive to learning. The program promises world class preceptors, individualized learning plans, and a supportive learning environment.  This was not my experience.  It really depends on which department and which preceptor you get.  There doesn't seem to be any organization once you get to the department level.  In my first 9 shifts, I had 3 different preceptors and 4 different managers (all with conflicting expectations).  For me, it was not a good fit.  That said, if you can get in and survive, you will have an amazing career ahead of you.

job_title: in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
I have worked for Stanford HealthCare for a number of years. I chose to join Stanford to be a part of the leading edge care and research happening here. My family has received lifesaving care at Stanford; which makes this place all the more special to me. It is easy to connect the work you do each day to improving the lives of our patients.  The vision and values of the organization resonate personally with me. 

The Talent Acquisition team (Recruitment) at Stanford is the most talented and engaged team I have ever been a part of.  We have an amazingly diverse team. The varying backgrounds and experiences of this team promotes a wealth of wonderful ideas and opportunities to enhance our work and make us stronger as a team.  Did I mention we have fun?  We have a very positive team that enjoys going to Giants Games, Warrior Games, walks and spending time with each other outside of the workplace. 

The new director has created flexible work schedules and advocated for the best systems and resources for our team. She has respectfully challenged the status-quo, which has helped the team garner trust and respect from our hiring partners and hospital leaders. Most importantly, her positive attitude and approach has improved engagement within our team and the entire HR function.

job_title: in Palo Alto, CA

cons: It is very VERY difficult to work with people who degrade you, and make you feel useless. People never forget how others made them feel, and working for the organization for such a short time I was really hurt. At the end of it all I felt like it was all about the numbers! Press Ganey patient satisfaction reports and getting 95% or higher on all the clinic categories. I have never met such rude people in my life where I would have tears in my eyes after work. In the beginning it was great, and somehow everything changed. I honestly did not feel like a team member, a valued employee, and this really broke me down. I will never forget how some members made me feel. I really thought Stanford Hospital & Clinic was a superb place to work because of all the great comments I heard the organization. However, once when I started it really was not like how people said it would be.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: PTO accrual, special events, cafeteria and AYR.
cons:
Supported Manager was not the Manager who completed my reviews and was not the person listed as my manager in HR. Not a win-win situation. That changed after I left, but it may still exist somewhere within SHC.  

PTO accrual.

30-minute lunch meant you'd dash to the Cafeteria or the Grab-N-Go and end up trying to eat your lunch at your desk because there was not enough seating in the cafeteria .  If you at your desk, people just didn't think you were at lunch, but working.  

Too stressful and caustic environment.  Stress leads to health problems, the most important being overweight. That shouldn't happen in a  healthcare organization caring for patients.

review_title: Poor treatment of Clinical lab scientists
job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Many interesting clinical cases you can learn from. I can't speak for other lab teams, but our group has great teamwork.
cons: Highly stressful workplace with poor compensation and benefits compared to other institutions. Clinical lab scientists are treated like work horses and the Clin Lab upper management is not interested in advocating or providing support to lab employees. No one in upper management had any experience working at Stanford Clinical Lab as a CLS, therefore they do not have much knowledge of what happens in the lab. They have not taken the time to learn and understand it either. Their interest lies in promoting themselves and keeping their jobs. There is not much intellectual or career advancement for CLS. The lab employees are hardly appreciated and respected by Hospital management and the rest of the clinical departments.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits, friendly staffs, good food
cons: Not diverse, traffic, commute, hard interview

job_title: Clinical Nurse I in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great new grad program. Supportive!
cons: Parking is difficult and confusing

job_title: Clinical Nurse in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, smart colleagues and clinical experts in every field.. Very interesting and challenging populations to care and learn from.
cons:
A work environment with no autonomy and and told what to do. Many processes in place to benefit the higher ups and make them look good.  Magnet culture is a girls and boys club with a “ cheer leading show and pageant like” to cover everyone’s lack of knowledge and true support to clinical excellence. The words of innovation and Department of Excellence are thrown around and promoted with no sound basis and do not show qualities of true Excellence or true authentic qualities.  Lots of high profile traveling for special
People and not equally distributed among employees. Many long tenured employees with self serving agendas to promote themselves and not the profession of nursing. Preferential treatment and cherry picking nurses for positions if you fit a Ken or Barbie prototype. Disappointing quality and clinical support system for actual bedside nurse. Instead money squandered on lunches and events to celebrate magnet meetings and looking good events. Address the real people doing the work and the real problems and perhaps the environment can stop being on a hamster wheel and circus show. New CNO does show hope, perhaps clean your leadership house and the card game will change!

job_title: in Stanford, CA
pros: The Physicians, Physician Assistants, Nurse Practitioners, Medical Assistants and the rest of the support staff are caring, dedicated people.  They treat their patients with respect as well as their colleagues.  They pay well although they do not treat every employee fairly.  See the cons.
cons: The Stanford Cancer Center Administration is too top heavy with inefficient managers.  They have no clinical skills and do not treat the staff with respect.  They are unfair, judgemental and unprofessional.  Stanford Cancer Center used to be an excellent, caring place to work for but with the changes in upper management, it has become a cold, inefficient place to work.  The employees feel they cannot give constructive input without feeling afraid of the consequences of speaking out.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great team members. Good organization. I left before David Entwistle took over, but Amir Dan Rubin was/is a phenomenal leader.
cons: I think much can be said about the first few months of employment, and how new hires are brought up to speed with the inner workings of his/her department, who to reach out to for help, expectations of the position, so on and so forth. Your manager should make YOU a priority. If check-in's are not a weekly or biweekly thing, I suggest you make them so and keep your manager in the loop with how you're doing. Stanford Health Care has become far too big, involved and complex for some administrators/managers' own good.

review_title: Great Hospital... but why make your staff pay for parking.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I loved my time at Stanford. I gained experience and felt there was good opportunity for growth. The pay wasn't the highest in the area but they do pay well and offer good 401k match. Better 401k then any job I have had since. Over staff the staff is wonderful nurses are highly educated and good team players.
cons:
Sick time and vacation time should be in separate banks. 
Nurses should go from hourly to Salary. Salary nurses would be much happier knowing each time the census was low they didn't have to lose money or dip into vacation banks for hours. I now work salary and love it as a staff nurse. After two hours of work in a week you get paid for overtime but are not charged for leaving early. It really creates accountability. 
Also Standford your so wealthy, please stop charing your staff especially the lowest paid staff for parking. Honestly it make staff annoyed. I know parking can be an issue but seriously its a small thing to add to staff feeling appreciated.

review_title: Left SHC after two weeks, work environment depends on specific department
job_title: Clinical Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Forward-thinking and some real innovators in the top-tier leadership along with expert clinicians and team dynamics really contribute to an great learning environment. Clinic staff went above and beyond and were very welcoming to the team. Great learning environment for healthcare trainees of all disciplines. Reasonable compensation and benefits when compared to cost of living of the area.
cons: Challenging inpatient nursing culture with some departments having unhealthy working environments with clear unilateral nursing violence. Unfortunately, I encountered a toxic work environment on the inpatient side that compelled me to leave my inpatient nursing position shortly after signing on. In some cases, patient care documentation is over-emphasized at the expense of patient care.

review_title: Disappointing considering it's the Stanford brand
job_title: Social Worker in Stanford, CA
pros: Great benefits, good wages but doesn't keep pace with the cost of living here, many opportunities for professional growth and development.
cons: The culture is petty, unprofessional at times among people who should be professional. Also very cliquish, narrow-minded, and vindictive even at the management level. There is not enough diversity but they appear to be working on it. It feels like high school working here. I shouldn't have but I expected better conduct given the name and reputation of the organization. The area is unaffordable and the commute to more affordable housing is long.

job_title: Clinic Assistant II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Benefits and Patient service  .culture
cons: Working at the Eye Institute is a Nightmare . Managers are not qualified employees feel like they are not appreciated and over worked. Drs over book patients for revenue and Don't care about quality of care they just want to see as many patients as they can for revenue.  Most of the employees complain about how horrible managers are and have no knowledge  of how the clinic is supposed to run . all of the employees are stressed and have health issues due to being overworked.

job_title: Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The brand name gives you a lot of recognition when interacting with other companies.
cons:
The commute here is really bad for anyone who doesn't live in the South bay (and it's even bad for those people). Their commuting options are subpar in comparison to other companies in the area.

The pay for software employees is 25%-40% less than the rest of the market. You're told that if you do well and add value, that you will get compensated. But they actually don't give raises to anyone. So if you come in low, you will be low forever (FYI). The pay is NOT competitive and many great candidates are lost because of insulting offers. 

The health benefits are poor considering that you work for a hospital. You get better health benefits at other hospitals or tech companies within the area. UCSF, Kaiser, Sutter Health are all better options. Don't be fooled by the name. If you have other options, take them (just a warning, I didn't take the other jobs offered to me and I definitely regret it). 

Promotions and the overall environment are bureaucratic. HR (who is supposed to work for the employee) does not respect you or your cases unless you have a Sr. Manager title.

job_title: IT
pros: Relative job security, health care will always be needed.
cons:
No annual performance based  raise or bonus opportunities.  Annual performance reviews completely disconnected  from annual raise or bonus.

No incentive to work hard  as regardless of being a star performer or the poorest performer, you are still only eligible for the same measly cost of living annual raise.

No annual bonus for individual contributors, only for managers.

Poor work-life balance. Because SHC is hospital, work is often 24/7, when things break, be ready to work all hours of day/night and weekends without overtime or extra pay.

IT department has been through multiple rounds of layoffs over past few years and rumor is department is still over budget.

Bait and switch,: SHC likes to claim its world class status, and maybe they treat the clinical side of the house in a world class manner, but not the non-clinical IT department. IT department pay is low, moral is low, turnover is high.

job_title: Staff RN in Stanford, CA
pros: good pay, great facility, well equipped. excellent morale, from what I've seen, and most staff seem truly caring and dedicated to patients and family. good food!
cons:
disorganized, lumbering bureaucracy. physician culture obstructively competitive and aggressive. nursing culture emphasizes sacrifice to the team to compensate for inadequate staffing. stanford thinks it's cutting edge, but from what I've seen, practice is not necessarily evidence based. resistant to change:  I've heard variations on "we've always done it this way" and "if it were the right thing to do, we'd already be doing it" numerous times. 

employees pay for parking and continuing education.

job_title: Physician Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros:
Stanford combines intellectual curiosity and innovation with caring, compassionate care. I work with great people and feel respected as an advanced practice provider. Benefits and salary are excellent

Silicon Valley is a beautiful place to live with a Mediterranean climate and plenty of open space very close to San Francisco. Stanford University has an excellent Arts and cultural events: the Jazz festival, great performances, the Mothers Day Pow wow, free art Museums, Rodin sculpture garden ,  Papua New Guinea sculpture garden, many sculptures throughout campus, and great lectures.
cons:
Housing is very expensive. It is why our salaries are so high. While the university has programs to help faculty afford their houses, this is not the case for hospital or clinic employees.

Also, as with all of health care: there is lots of work to be done. We have a good team.

job_title: Physician Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
HR/Recruiting reps respectfully afforded me ample explanation of the complex rubric used by their department during the on-boarding process. Specific details regarding input factors were shared to help me understand this rubric, and their perception of my personal history and professional abilities was clearly apparent upon receiving their offer letter.
  The staff gave proper attention to the long road it took for me to get where I am now.  And whereas past employers have acknowledged my prior work and life experiences, I often felt they were just entries on my resume. 
  This was not the case with Stanford.  They gave me credit for my hard work, and although I never expected my history to set me apart from others, their detailed rubric has greatly restored a level of personal pride, thus reinforcing confidence and positive self-reflection.
cons: Lengthy credentialing process which is typical, and expected, in the medical field

job_title: Resident in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
-Good benefits: medical/dental/vision, use of gym, free Caltrain GoPass and VTA Ecopass, Marguerite shuttle, etc. 
-Other residents are generally nice.
-Radiology dept is excellent, and happy to teach/show/discuss. Amazing since they area abused with so many unnecessary scans ordered.
cons:
-A lot of wasted resources (but that is the health care system, so you'll get that most places).
-ER is clinically poor. 
-Defensive medicine galore. Wasted resources. 
-Nursing is overpaid and Stanford cultivates a culture of empowerment for them. Many nice outwardly, but passive/aggressive, and will go way above your head if any issue. Must walk on eggshells around. Difficult to do 24-7-365. This is magnified 100x in the children's hospital. 
-Negativity b/w specialties. 
-Not enough food money. Uh, we work 80hrs a week and don't make any money since we're residents. Think you could spot us some food money? Most hospitals do. 
-Pay too low compared to cost of living in Silicon Valley. Often scraping by.

review_title: Great location, very professional collegues,excellent benefits,  poor executive managment
job_title: Manager in Stanford, CA
pros: The professional environment, world class health care, excellent benefits and really great co-workers all make for a great place to work. The pay is pretty competitive. Managment does attempt to reach out to employees through gallup polls. The location is fabulous, places to walk, eat are just numerous. The hospital offers and encourages music breaks (concerts are offered free during lunch hour) and helps with growth opportunities.
cons:
The senior management as in every institution is plagued with inability to reach grass-roots. There is quite a bit of shuffling of the same people in various roles, so, new talent is not really seen much.
The employee turn over in the past year has been quite extensive, thus investment and loyalty to the institution need to be focused on. Employee retention has become quite a challenge in the past year.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Free public transportation (CalTrain/VTA), good networking opportunities.  Plenty of lateral movement opportunities.  Entry level salaries higher than University admin jobs.
cons: Talent Acquisition (recruiters) ruthlessly lowball salary.  True COL increases only   available via promotion or title change.  Little/no career track for admin roles, unless you are male.  Managers turnover so frequently they are not well trained on employment laws and violate them, protected only by the 'he said she said' rule.  Cowboy culture in certain clinic settings.

job_title: Nurse Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great pay for managers. Looks good on resume. New executives coming in and a new chief nursing officer. The new CEO seems to appreciate nurses.
cons: Not sure if the new CNO will be good or changes will trickle down. Many (not all) of middle nursing management shows blatant favoritism, gossips, political, and obstructive to change. Those individuals do not support their front line nurse managers. "Why didn't you get this done?" "I stayed over my 8 hour shift to be charge nurse and prevent staff overtime. Aren't you glad I'm saving the hospital money and working so hard?" "Yes but I'm disappointed and holding you accountable for this not being done."... Things like this are why many are burned out and feel underappreciated.

job_title: NP/Pa in Stanford, CA
pros: In my specialty, I have a lot of autonomy and a collaborative working relationship with physicians.  I feel my clinical decision making is respected.  Also, the staff NP/PAs are empowered in my service line to contribute to the organization.  We also have an Advanced Practice Provider General Council that is structured well and has a voice.  The administration for NPs and PAs is very responsive and has created a healthy work environment.  We even now have a career ladder that recognizes our hard work through a promotion and salary adjustment.
cons: It is true, I have some colleagues in some departments who have a lot of shared visits with their physicians.  Also, the cost of living in the area is very high.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Incredible opportunities to learn and work with some of the best of the best. Decent pay for the area.
cons: Very dysfunctional work environment and a lot of un-qualified senior management who rose to high positions not based on merit but on who they knew. HR cannot be trusted. Stanford does not let internal candidates know that management jobs are open and they do not promote from within unless you know someone. Jobs are mostly filled without internal candidates being aware that some positions are open. Most of Stanford's IT Directors do not put patient care first.  They encourage back-stabbing and unhealthy competition among staff. It is a lion's den and not a "fun" place to work. It is a "cubicle" environment. They pretend to care about promoting professional growth unless it threatens their own positions. Stanford does not care about work/life balance. You will work harder than you have ever worked before. They believe that it is a privilege to work there so they are not concerned about employee turnover.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros:
- Benefits
- Caltrain/VTA pass
- More Social Workers should use this website to post salaries and reviews so there is more transparency and more advancement
cons:
- Low morale in the Social Work department
- No transparency, from salary ranges to open positions, mistrust between management and Social Workers
- Favoritism in hiring and promotions
- Salary varies widely 
- No emphasis on experience or longevity so that they can hire brand new Social Work grads to pay them low, with little to no orientation, training and support (bad way to start off a career)
- High turnover with Social Workers
- Managers only interested in the bottom line
- Little job security (fear of retaliation)
- Lack of support from management
- Lack of humanity by management towards current employees, little work/life balance
- No union so no protections of salary or basic advancements through career
- Hospital under construction so lot's of hassle getting to/from work, expensive parking

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Most of the team, which consists of HR Partners and HR Generalist, work really well with each other.  Most of everyone is very nice and you get to work with the other departments (Benefits, Compensation, TA) on a day to day basis.
cons:
Leadership has no clue how to take care of their employees.  There is no flexibility because you're tied to a phone schedule, the generalist/partner role is more like a data entry specialist position, and you'll always want to be aware of who you interact with because they have their favorites and they have their blacklists.  Associate accordingly.  

This place is way too political.  In a short time (5.5 months), there have been 7 resignations, which is why there are so many operations positions available---3 HR Partners, 1 Compliance Manager, 1 Project Manager and 2 Generalists.  I think that says enough about why you should avoid this department at all costs....

job_title: Clinical Systems Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Remote work.  Opportunities to work on projects that are interesting and things that most haven't done before.  Most of the medical staff are great to work with.  Resume builder.  People are genuinely impressed to hear that you work for "Stanford."
cons: Overworked.  Short staffed.  Certain medical staff are bullying and demanding and leadership does nothing to control it.  There is a difference between innovating and doing things within the system that just aren't possible.  Certain PMs will make promises and badmouth the analysts when these things just aren't possible.  Reorg which seemed to be the promotion of a bunch of managers, and no word about analyst promotions.

job_title: Laboratory Support Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great process and adherence to procedural methods. Good leadership. Wonderful, dedicated people to work with. Opportunities to learn are available as is a chance to work on the latest Epic releases. All in all, a very solid and reliable laboratory systems team.
cons: Very intense. Some of the leads are so aggressive they scare people away. Very, very high volume of laboratory orders and results. Downtime causes the worst to come out in some of the leadership. Not quite panic, just overly reactive. Very much micro management at its worst in some departments. Also, some departments always want to blame others for their own lack of initiative.

review_title: Talent Acquisition at Stanford Health Care
job_title: Talent Acquisition in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
I love how my department (Talent Acquisition) at Stanford Health Care has helped me to grow and develop professionally.  We are very much encouraged to attend relevant training courses.  As an example, practically our entire department (and we’re pretty sizeable) is now AIRS certified (and in more than one area).  The training expenses were all taken care of for us….the recruiters did not have to pay a cent.  Some of us are now pursuing other certifications in HR and/or Talent Acquisition.  

I am being paid to do what I love to do here at Stanford Health Care (can’t beat that!).  It is a joy and privilege for me to work here.
cons: The benefits are pretty good but not great.  There is a 403B plan but no pension plan anymore

review_title: Good place for grad school; choose your lab carefully
job_title: PhD Student in Stanford, CA
pros: The professors here are some of the best in their field or are up and coming and doing exciting work; there are no big problems with funding; there is a sizable grad student community, and they are currently working on improving the education experience for grad students
cons: A large part of your grad school experience depends on what lab you join and what project you choose.  If you choose your lab/adviser and project wisely, you will probably do well and enjoy grad school.  However, at the beginning of grad school, it is difficult to know how to best select an adviser and project, leading to frustration and unhappiness after several years of grad school.  Also, I had a difficult time dealing with a variety of unusual administrative issues during grad school; the people in the registrar's office are not particularly helpful and I ended up relying on department administrators to help me navigate the system.

review_title: Great place to work! Highly Recommend!
job_title: Senior Talent Acquisition Consultant in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Senior management is very supportive and open to interesting new projects that will make your job more efficient
Coworkers are passionate about healthcare and very patient centric
The work itself is challenging and dynamic
Professional working environment with a twist of fun
Managers want to help you obtain your ultimate career goal and willing to support
Company growth is tremendous with new clinics and brand new hospital
Benefits are great
Tons of resources available to each employee, which always employees to be productive
cons:
Get ready to work! Can be very fast paced
Cost of living is high

review_title: I expected better... I was sorely let down.
job_title: General Services in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Pay, Medical and thats about it... really...
cons: If you value self respect, don't go to work for SHC.  CEO Amir Dan Rubens agenda is to expand SHC (in other words, his) empire.  Even at the expense of his employees.  Management is a joke, especially in the General Services department.  They micro manage EVERYTHING and treat their subordinates like children and attempt's to stand up for yourself is swiftly dealt with as if you are forming an insurrection.  Preception is paramount,  and the reality is dismissed.  The CI Care format is crammed down our throats and it is expected to be followed as scripture.  Speaking of that,  we are basically walking scripts with the fake Pan Am smile.  God forbid we are seen as human by the patients or visitors... or worse the families.  The work enviorment is toxic and hostile for lack of better words...

review_title: Stanford: Overconfident grandiose self image instead of true advancement
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Stanford, CA
pros: Looks good on a resume. Night get free parking. 5$ gift card bonus/yr.
cons: I feel that Stanford administration spends all their time touting the grand state of affairs (employee satisfaction, good outcomes, and national rankings), but they don't look ahead to see what they could do to improve patient and employee conditions.  My unit does not have a break nurse, frequently understaffed, encouraged to NOT bring up the fact that we are understaffed, not given full break time, and employees are encouraged to clock out on time even if you have more work to do (dangerous to the nurse re license and continuation of care).

review_title: A positive experience, as I'm well-supported on the clinical side and doing cutting edge science.
job_title: Clinical Instructor in Stanford, CA
pros: A preeminent institution that is forward thinking, fast moving, exciting, and innovative on the science side--and very solid on the clinical side.  I am proud to be a part of the Stanford medical and scientific community.
cons: The sometimes inefficient workings of an academic medical center can be frustrating for patients to deal with, and it can be awkward to explain this to patients.  At Stanford, although patient care is highly valued and is generally at an extremely high level, the focus is on research.  Routine medical problems are often more smoothly taken care of at non-academic centers.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working towards a common goal while meeting some awesome people.
cons: MGMT's ability to remove the only leadership that WAS working and the ability to hire managers that are more concerned with egos and titles than doing the actual work. Putting people in power positions that are so far removed from patient care and honestly, have no business being in healthcare. They would rather work for Google or FB. They will destroy the organization from the inside out. It's has already begun

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I love my coworkers. I also love the amazing experience of working in such a respected teaching hospital as well as the knowledge gained. I feel like an active and important member of the treatment team.
cons: Management.  It is poor. I have had a number of patient care managers in my unit in just a handful of years and each seems worse than the one before. They have very poor communication skills and even worse leadership skills.

review_title: Oppressive People-Management at Hospital Information Technology
job_title: Information Technology in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Many openings, competitive salary on a 40-hr work week basis (see below)
cons: A part of the group within Hospital IT is being subjected to verbally (not written) continuous 24/7 work schedule for weeks on end on rotation for exempt employees. Overseas staff covering overnight support work is being let go and their support (non-exempt) work is being added to exempt staff as a cost-cutting measure resulting in 24/7 work hours on weekdays, weekends and holidays with *no* overtime compensation or comp time or regard for employees' health or wellness. Requests to redress this situation have been ignored by management and HR denies this to be the policy. No written document has been officially circulated and this policy is being enforced verbally (and currently followed). No HR or Senior Management oversight.

review_title: working at stanford university medical center prepares you to handle" politics" in academia research
job_title: CRA in Palo Alto, CA
pros: You get an exposure to how research in academia really works. The association with Stanford as a name is a positive thing if you don't mind the politics.  You meet a lot of very smart and nice people. You can get discounts if you choose to take a course at  Stanford university. As an employee, you can use the fancy church as you wedding location.
cons:
The senior managment  is a mess. Some PI 's big have some huge egos. I think that the well being of the patients should come first and not the big Egos of principal investigators.

The salaries are also low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Benefits are good, but it is nearly impossible to advance to better job opportunities.
cons: The employees with multiple high ranking outstanding educational degrees have a different experience from the regular workers, who have difficulty in getting promotions. Unless you are in the late X-Generation, and are very close friends with someone who is in a position to hire, you will never get promoted or move to a better opportunity.

review_title: Great Working Environment, Admin Can Be Hit or Miss
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Competitive pay and great working environment, save from few coworkers who may not adhere to CICARE, stonewalling and bullying because they take things personally and want things done their way or how it has always been.
Otherwise, laid back pace of work-style and straightforward expectations from employees.

review_title: Blood Collections Dept only: dysfunctional organization despite glossy facade
job_title: Blood Bank Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Great employees to work with
- Stanford University benefits
- Free refreshments (cookies, pretzels, juices, coffee)
- Every other month employee appreciation little event (usually cookies or cupcakes delivered to 3 fixed sites, which unfortunately doesn't undo all the "damage" done with poor scheduling and micromanagement)
- Guaranteed breaks throughout the work day (broken down to 15min, 30min, 15min for >6hrs days)
cons:
- I was hired full-time, every single week have to figure out how to get those 40 hours due to short-hour mobiles. I have to trade my shifts with other employees to make up for poor schedule.
- Pay for Registered Nurses 50-60% less than in a hospital (even as a new grad). And this is while living in the most expensive area in the country.
- Because of poor pay need the 2nd job but unable to hold one because the schedule is EXTREMELY unpredictable and changes all the time (example of week 1: Monday 7:30a-2:45p, Tuesday 12p-8:30p, Wednesday 5:45a-3p, Thursday/Friday - off, Saturday 10a-5p, Sunday 8:15a-2:30p; the next week days off are on Monday and Sunday, the week after off on Tuesday and Sunday and so on). 
- Schedule is given 4 weeks in advance but subject to change and changes often to cover sick calls and busy operations.
- Hard to schedule doctor's appointments, kids' activities because of schedule. One time I rescheduled my doctor's appointment 5 times to accommodate my ever-changing schedule.
- Most employees work >75% of weekend days.  
- Very high turnover rate. Out of 50-55 collections department employees (phlebotomists and RNs who draw blood from donors) >15 left in the last 14 months.
- Management doesn't focus on retention of employees but on how to hire more. They hire 3 times a year 4 or more people each time.
- Training department had to expand (hired 2 full-time trainers in the last 12 months to a total of 5 trainers) to keep up with training of new employees because they cannot train fast enough due to employees leaving too soon  
- Vacation request has to be done by December 15 of previous year for summer months of next year. If not requested so early ahead, there is no guarantee that even one vacation day off will be granted in the summer. Even for other months it's tedious to request vacation and is still not guaranteed. Management says that "we're open to work with you" but the outcome often doesn't reflect the statement.
- Many accrued sick hours available but it's frowned upon when one calls in sick. If it's done on Saturday, Sunday, or Monday, then management can reprimand for sick calls creating "a pattern", which can be reflected in performance review. 
- Being on-call on weekends pays ZERO to be ready at 6-7am on a day off. If they call, then the pay is the same as on weekdays unless one already worked 40hrs this week. In this case pay is 50% for being overtime, no other additional pay for being on-call. If they don't call, then one gets paid nothing, hence not many employees want to be on-call and weekend work days become that much more hectic to work due to understaffing.
- No differential for late and weekend shifts.
- Chronic understaffing. Example: a 3-staff small bus was sent to a company that scheduled 27 donor appointments in 4 hours. When asked SBC mobile coordinator why not a bigger bus was sent to such a busy mobile, one received an answer "Because there's not enough staff to work". 
- Big emphasis on great customer service delivered to employees while employees have to explain donors why wait is so long because they are understaffed
- 2 full-time and 1 part-time schedulers have a hard time figuring out the schedule of 50-55 employees, which results in many errors such as one scheduled to clock in at one time while the rest of the team 45min earlier.

review_title: Good place to work, but unsustainable.
job_title: Steam Plant Engineer in Stanford, CA
pros:
I worked in one of Stanford Health Care's (SHC) blue collar, craft positions that supported the people that provided patient care, not as one of the medical professionals or medical technicians.
With that said, I have a long history in working in other industries, with mostly for-profit companies and it was a pleasure to come into the non-profit, human service world. Stanford requires "all" of its employees to study and fully understand its C-I-Care program, which guides  SHC employees (medical and support staff) in patient care and treatment of visitors. SHC takes  C-I-Care's guidelines and extends them as guidelines to employee-to-employee relationships. I was pleased to work in an atmosphere that, for the most part, was non-competitive and where employees supported each other, rather than undercut each other.
cons:
Two departments that effect each employee, HR and IT appear to be a bit bureaucratic and remote. For the most part, when things go well they run as a well oiled machine. But when an error that effects the employee happens, it takes far too long and has to pass through too many hands to get resolved.
As noted by other reviewers, the cost of housing in the Bay Area (as in many US metropolitan areas) is far too high, even for good paying blue collar, craft positions. Santa Clara and San Mateo counties (SHC's center) are the worst of that. Many employees are subject to very long commutes aggravated by scheduled 10-12 workdays. SHC should consider a moratorium on anything but eight hour workdays.
